thread.title: ‘Britain must suffer the consequences!’ Macron to deliver stern Brexit warning to London
thread.title_full: ‘Britain must suffer the consequences!’ Macron to deliver stern Brexit warning to London

title: ‘Britain must suffer the consequences!’ Macron to deliver stern Brexit warning to London
text:
‘Britain must suffer the consequences!’ Macron to deliver stern Brexit warning to London ‘Britain must suffer the consequences!’ Macron to deliver stern Brexit warning to London THE favourite to become France's new president is calling for Britain to 'suffer the consequences' for shunning the European Union. PUBLISHED: 12:36, Tue, Feb 21, 2017 | UPDATED: 12:59, Tue, Feb 21, 2017 GETTY/AFP Emmanuel Macron will use his anti-Brexit speech to win the vote of French people living in the UK 
Emmanuel Macron's tough anti-Brexit message to be delivered in London today is part of an offensive that he hopes will win over some 300,000 plus French voters living in Britain. 
Many fear the future after UK withdrawal, and will pack Westminster Central Hall this afternoon to seek reassurances from the 39-year-old independent. 
Mr Macron said last week: “If your government decides to organise a Brexit, I will be pretty tough on it.” Related articles Macron brings his campaign to LONDON as he eyes up French expat votes 
The former investment banker told Channel 4 News: “We have to preserve the rest of the European Union , and not convey the message that you can decide to leave without any consequences.” 
London has attracted huge numbers of French workers in recent years, including many working in the financial sector. 
Mr Macron has pledged to ensure that they are not turned into pawns by Britain as it negotiates its way out of the EU. GETTY Macron is the favourite to become the new president of France 
He is particularly insistent that there will be no EU passport and 'no access to the single market' for the British after a hard Brexit , adding: “It is not a matter of punishing but of being consistent with such a decision.” It is not a matter of punishing but of being consistent Emmanuel Macron 
The latest IFOP opinion poll in France has Mr Macron coming second to far-right National Front leader Marine Le Pen in the first round of the presidential elections in April, and then crushing her by 61.5 per cent to 38.5 in the second round in May. 
French people registered to vote abroad can cast their ballot in the presidential poll, and most in London are members of France's northern Europe parliamentary constituency. 
Mr Macron has raised millions of pounds worth of campaign funds from overseas events, and is set to meet some 'big names' today, so as to boost his profile, according to aides. Marion Le Pen in pictures Wed, July 27, 2016 The niece of French far-right leader Marine Le Pen has joined the military reserve and has urged "young patriots" to follow in her footsteps, take a look through her career to date, AFP/Getty Images 1 of 12 French far right Front National (National Front - FN) party's Parliament member and candidate for the regional elections in the Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur (PACA) 
One source in En Marche! (On the move!), Macron's new progressive movement said: “Emmanuel has a huge number of supporters in France. 
“He is offering a dynamic, pro-Europe outlook aimed to appeal to those who have had enough of the cynicism of other politicians.” 
Ms Le Pen is currently at the centre of a corruption enquiry involving alleged fake jobs, as is the conservative Republican candidate Francois Fillon, who employed his Wales born wife, Penelope, on a lucrative taxpayer-funded contract while she allegedly did nothing at all. GETTY Marine Le Pen has become embroiled in a corruption scandal 
Both are facing criminal charges before the election, and are also extremely close to Russia, which is said to be launching cyber attacks against Mr Macron Jean-Marc Ayrault, France's foreign minister, said at the weekend: “It's enough just to look at the candidates - Marine Le Pen and Francois Fillon - for whom Russia is expressing preferences, while Emmanuel Macron, who has a very pro-European stance, is undergoing cyber attacks. 
'This form of interference in French democratic life is unacceptable and I condemn it.” Related articles
